Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1724998 Brezinsky

This project is to provide partial travel supports to students who will attend the 10th International Conference on Chemical Kinetics, to be held in Chicago, May 21 to 25, 2017. This award is anticipated to support 50 students, each with $200 to offset their travel costs. Attending a conference is essential to enrich the educational experience of graduate students. The experience in interacting with other participants will stimulate novel ideas and further motivate students to pursue advanced research. In particular, this international conference will bring together experts across the world. The participating students from the U.S. institutions will gain rare opportunities to learn from many international experts. Such an experience will be very valuable and can help advance the research capabilities of the U.S. institutions.

This biennial conference brings together experts from university, research laboratories, and industrial organization to exchange knowledge in theoretical and experimental chemical kinetics. This cross-disciplinary meeting highlights the importance of fundamental understanding of elementary reactions to the full range of chemical investigations in both gas and condensed phases. The presentations also include studies of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions and polymer engineering. This conference provide a unique forum to discuss how the same reactive species and reaction motifs manifest under very different reaction conditions. Particularly, gas phase chemical kineticists and liquid phase catalyst scientists can learn from each other. The results of such learning will further expand scientific understanding of the complex chemical reaction paths and outcomes. These knowledge will help engineers design cleaner and more efficient combustion or energy conversion devices, which will benefit the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Conference on Chemical Kinetics (ICCK) was established in 1985 in Gaithersburg at the National Institute of Standards to bring together investigators from universities, research laboratories, and industrial organizations to review progress and problems in theoretical and experimental chemical kinetics. This cross-disciplinary meeting highlights the importance of fundamental understanding of elementary reactions to the full range of chemical investigations in both gas and condensed phases.  The scope was further broadened at the 9th ICCK to include studies of heterogeneously catalyzed reactions and polymer engineering. With its broadened scope and the cross-disciplinary research of its attendees, the ICCK meetings provide a unique forum to discuss how the same reactive species and reaction motifs manifest under very different reaction conditions.

The 10th International Conference on Chemical Kinetics was held at the University of Illinois at Chicago, May 21-25, 2017. There were 127 registered attendees. Three parallel technical sessions were offered throughout the conference. In addition to the scientific sessions, there were coffee breaks, social hour/poster sessions and a banquet all of which encouraged the cross disciplinary interaction that was one of the goals of the conference. 

One of the salient characteristics of the ICCK meetings is its international nature. The international character of the ICCK meeting affords U.S. citizen or permanent resident students of chemical kinetics the opportunity to meet, discuss, and network with other researchers in the global chemical kinetics community. The financial support of the NSF was used to make possible the attendance at the ICCK meeting by U.S. citizen or permanent resident graduate students and post-doctoral students. The number of student attending was much greater than the number that needed financial support since many of the students had means to pay for the registration and travel. For those who needed the financial support the NSF provided, the support was essential to their being able to attend. 

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2019
Modified by: Kenneth Brezinsky
